oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oral history interview with Douglas G. Odom, Jr., 2007 June 05
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Excerpts from an interview with Madison businessman Douglas G. Odom, Jr., conducted on 05 June 2007 by James T. Havron as part of the Nashville Business Leaders Oral History Project. In the excerpts, Odom discusses his family's business, Odom's Tennessee Pride Sausage, including the role his mother, Louise Odom, played in the businesses' success; his service in the Marine Corps; how his grandfather and father got started in the meat industry; how his father started the sausage business with a loan from Henry Powell, a family friend; the involvement of his entire family in the business; the company's involvement with the American Meat Institute; the creation of the trademark farm boy icon; how the company has focused its advertising over the years; the success of Odom's Tennessee Pride Sausage as a small business; the strength of his business competitors; his mother's role as crew chief for the sausage wrappers; and the role copyright has played in protecting the company's trademark. The complete interview, as well as an index, is available in the Special Collections Division.
